review.title: Standard State Space Models of Unawareness (Extended Abstract)
review.abstract: The impossibility theorem of Dekel, Lipman and Rustichini has been thought to demonstrate that standard state-space models cannot be used to represent unawareness. We first show that Dekel, Lipman and Rustichini do not establish this claim. We then distinguish three notions of awareness, and argue that although one of them may not be adequately modeled using standard state spaces, there is no reason to think that standard state spaces cannot provide models of the other two notions. In fact, standard space models of these forms of awareness are attractively simple. They allow us to prove completeness and decidability results with ease, to carry over standard techniques from decision theory, and to add propositional quantifiers straightforwardly.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Dekel, Lipman and Rustichini [8], hereinafter referred to as DLR, claim to show that "standard spatial models exclude the unconscious." Their assertion has acquired the status of orthodoxy. [1] The first task of this essay is to clear the way for standard spatial models of the unconscious by showing that the formal result of DLR does not justify their headline-grabbing conclusion.DLR informally motivates certain axioms with regard to the unconscious, but in their formal impossibility they lead to the assertion that these axioms apply in all states of the model. As Section 2 argues, the assumption that axioms apply in all states of the model is unwarranted; in fact, DLR itself rejects formal results, but they are not sufficiently general to exclude standard spatial models of the unconscious. As we show, the impossibility does not persist if one assumes only the explicit assumption in some. "

sections.heading: 3.1 A New Triviality Result
sections.text: The result of DLR had limited effects on state spatial models because it depended on the validity of their axioms in all states. Is there a triviality result that applies only the validity of axioms to consciousness in real states, rather than to their validity in all states? Indeed, as we now show, commonly accepted axioms to consciousness lead to triviality, even if they are imposed only in real states. The result uses the following two axioms: AS: A ¬ p → ApAC: A (p) q) → (Ap) Consciousness is widely assumed to be satisfied with both of these axioms; see, for example, [43, pp. 274-275], [18, pp. 331] (Axioms A1 and A2) and [25, p. 309] (Axioms 1 and 2).

sections.heading: 3.2 Attending vs. Conceiving vs. Processing
sections.text: In the literature on consciousness, it is indisputable that there is not a single attitude of consciousness; what is expressed by "consciousness" is a loose collection of terms. This was noted at the very beginning of the literature, which is confirmed by the lengthy discussions in [10]; another detailed discussion can only be found in [55]. We will argue that at least some important terms of consciousness AC (for others, as we will see, the situation is more complex) cannot be satisfied. To do this, we roughly distinguish the following three ways of understanding the form "the agent is conscious.": (i) The agent takes care of it. (ii) The agent has the conceptual resources needed to grasp it. (iii) The agent is able to process these terms. We will introduce these terms - and distinguish between them - using various examples from literature.

sections.heading: 4.1 The Attitude of Attention
sections.text: In order to motivate partitional models as models of limited attention, we suggest that attention, in the sense in which we have used the term, should primarily be understood as an attitude towards questions. There are many formal approaches available to modelling questions (for an overview see [35]). Specifically, we will take a standard approach that presents questions as a division of state space (see [17], based on [23] and [32]). Although we believe that the attitude towards questions is primary, we will follow the literature on consciousness in order to axiomatise an idea of attention that has events as objects. The relationship between this attitude towards events and the attitude towards questions will be as follows: An agent will take care of the question Q, if and only if the agent addresses each partial word on Q.

sections.text: The present result shows that we can enforce the DLR axioms without trivializing partial models, but we admit that we have doubts as to whether these axioms are appropriate. Just as with AC, if we understand more clearly the character of attention and conceivability and the distinction between sentences and what they express, the DLR axioms lose traction. The clearest case concerns plausibility and attention. One consequence of the contrapositivity of plausibility is Kс → Aт. But this principle is wrong for attention. You know that there are more than four stars in the universe, but we doubt that you dealt with the question of how many stars there are before reading the previous clause. As we discuss in more detail throughout the paper, the coarse conception of the content, together with the clarity of the idea that consciousness should be modelled, casts doubt on the DLR axioms.

sections.heading: 5 Decision Theory
sections.text: In Section 4.5, the example of the number of stars illustrates how one can believe and know things in which one does not participate; clearly, this kind of inattention can also influence voting behavior. An advantage of standard state spaces is that we can use the usual decision-theoretical framework to represent the effects of inattention on voting behavior. 7The usual decision-theoretical representation of an agent's beliefs uses a measurement space < S, B, µ >.8 To generate a partial model, we enrich this description of the agent by selecting BC, a complete atomic subalgebra of B to produce a representation of what the agent pays attention to in the context of the election: < S, B, µ, BC >. The atoms of BC are a division of S so that this structure produces a partial model of ignorance. The distribution that the agent "uses" in an election context is given as Alzit (C = E) for certain events that can be interpreted as E for certain factors.

sections.text: Building on the work of [2], [41] Alice demonstrated her famous "no-trade" theorem, which illustrates the extreme strength of S5 knowledge together with a common earlier one. Accordingly, one goal of representing "limited" agents such as those with limited attention is to escape such paradoxes (for this perspective see [45], [38]). Accordingly, we are now providing a partial DLR model with a common earlier state in which speculative trading is possible. As is known (see [16], [50], [49]), the "no-trade" theorem generally does not apply if agent-accessibility relationships Ri are merely transitive and reflexive, but not necessary to form an equivalence relationship. Plausibility is incompatible with Ri, which forms an equivalence relationship ([42]).

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion
sections.text: Standardized state-space models of attention and conceivability are at least as successful as current non-standard state-space models. However, the non-standard models are more complicated, and it is unclear whether this complexity offers any advantages in terms of predictive power or accuracy. Standardized state-space models of these phenomena promise to lead to a rich and worthwhile theory that poses technical and conceptual challenges and links to related work by linguists, philosophers, and logicians - as well as to work on limited thinking elsewhere in economic theory.

metadata.abstractText: The impossibility theorem of Dekel, Lipman and Rustichini [8] has been thought to demonstrate that standard state-space models cannot be used to represent unawareness. We first show that Dekel, Lipman and Rustichini do not establish this claim. We then distinguish three notions of awareness, and argue that although one of them may not be adequately modeled using standard state spaces, there is no reason to think that standard state spaces cannot provide models of the other two notions. In fact, standard space models of these forms of awareness are attractively simple. They allow us to prove completeness and decidability results with ease, to carry over standard techniques from decision theory, and to add propositional quantifiers straightforwardly.
